cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive basic course in spoken and written French for students who have no knowledge of French: comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: French for Beginners

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). All students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week.

Students enrolling in LEC9901 (online sync) must choose an online TUT (TUT0101, TUT0102 or TUT0201).

Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the enrolment deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

Students with NO previous knowledge of French will enroll in this course and are NOT required to do the online placement test.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 8, 2021: section added.

cmCourseInfo.title: French for Beginners

notes.name: Course Note

Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). All students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week.

Students enrolling in LEC9901 (online sync) must choose an online TUT (TUT0101, TUT0102 or TUT0201).

Students enrolling in LEC9902 (online sync) must choose an online TUT (TUT0401, TUT0501 or TUT0601).

Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the enrolment deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

Students with NO previous knowledge of French will enroll in this course and are NOT required to do the online placement test.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive basic course in spoken and written French for students who have studied some French, but who have not yet attained the entry level for FSL121Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL100H1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). All students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week. 

Students enrolling in LEC9901 (online sync) must choose an online TUT (TUT0101, TUT0102 or TUT0201).

Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the enrolment deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students with a minimum knowledge of French.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intended for students having some knowledge of French but wishing to increase their proficiency to that of normal University entrance. Offers training in written and spoken French; reinforcement of reading comprehension and aural abilities; and an introduction to French-Canadian and Québécois cultures.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL102H1, or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 4-hour course (2-hr lecture, 2-hr tutorial). Students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of four hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the enrolment deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intended for those who have some knowledge of French, this course is the first in a proficiency-sequenced series that provides students with the opportunity to become proficient, focused, autonomous French language learners. Adopting a principally actional approach to second language learning targeting Level A2 objectives of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR); the course’s main objective is to provide a communicative learning environment through activities based in real-world, everyday contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL121Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 4-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr online asynchronous and 1-hr tutorial). Students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of four hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the enrolment deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

courses.name: Strategies for Autonomous Learning in French as a Second Language

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides French language learners with an understanding of how one best acquires French as a second or third language including various FSL strategies that allow for effective, autonomous learning. It further implements a structure to encourage continuous active reflection and self-assessment. Students will first learn about the types of knowledge and sub-skills that must be acquired to master French including vocabulary and grammar. Language benchmarks and self-evaluation tools are then introduced to help learners to profile their four main competences (reading, writing, listening, and speaking). Subsequently, they will receive practical training in the use of specific online resources (e.g., Bon Patron) geared towards improving French writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Strategies for Autonomous Learning in French as a Second Language
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: FSL321Y1, as determined by the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FRE226H1, FRE225Y1/JFI225Y1, FSL375H1, FSL375Y1, FSL415H1, FSL421Y1, FSL442H1, FSL443H1, FSL472H1, FSL473H1, FSL475H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: https://www.french.utoronto.ca/prospective-undergraduate-students/enrolment-guidelines

courses.name: Writing French: the Language of the Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Using current online French media, broaden your understanding of the French language; deepen your grammatical knowledge; expand your vocabulary (including idioms); review key aspects of French syntax; and fine-tune your reading skills in French. Weekly reading and writing workshops are an integral part of this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing French: the Language of the Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course is designed to enhance students’ existing knowledge of French by giving them a theoretical as well as a practical foundation in the use of French language in the workplace. Special emphasis will be placed on the appropriate vocabulary used within the context of communication in the Francophone workplace. Students will learn how to communicate in a variety of professional contexts as well as how to distinguish between the formal and informal styles of French suitable for diverse situations in the workplace. This course also aims to help students acquire intercultural skills needed in the Francophone workplace.

The redesigned course will provide a hybrid alternative that delivers the same high quality content and high degree of interaction present in traditional in-class course delivery. The new format will consist of weekly one-hour online sessions and two-hour traditional in-class sessions. In this format, further preparation work and homework will continue to be carried on as in the traditional course, i.e. outside of the 3-hour class time.
cmCourseInfo.title: French for the Workplace
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL, enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

Delivery Instructions

This is a 3-hour course. 2 hours in-class (WE 13h-15h) + 1 hour LEC Online Asynchronous

courses.name: French Oral Communication for Professional and Academic Contexts

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who wish to develop their oral communication skills in French in preparation for bilingual employment, community service, and academic activities in Canada and abroad. Emphasis is placed on the development of skills for accurate oral language use in professional and academic contexts: researched oral presentations, debates, interviews, and student-led discussions. Students will learn how to adapt their speaking style and register to different audiences and situations, use appropriate vocabulary, and self-correct.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Oral Communication for Professional and Academic Contexts
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL, enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL321Y1 and higher. Not open to fluent and native speakers of French.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course is intended for students who have already mastered the basic competences in French language proficiency. The textbook used in this course will follow the B1 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR) in its active approach which puts emphasis on the student being at the centre of the learning process. Students will learn the following intermediate-level language skills: writing, speaking as well as understanding written and spoken French.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL375Y1 and higher. May not be taken concurrently with any FSL31*H1 series courses.

cmCourseInfo.description: This half-year course, which works as an introduction to translation, is designed to improve students’ mastery of French through English to French and French to English translations. Emphasis is on the practice of translation of a variety of texts and documents, and on the introduction to the practice of oral interpretation from one language to the other.
cmCourseInfo.title: Practical Translation: French - English
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 1.0 credit in FSL at the 300-level, or any 1.0 credit in FRE at the 200-level

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced course in French including the reading and discussion of texts focussing on the francophone presence and influence in the international context. Emphasis is placed on mastery of complex linguistic skills via use of a variety of reference tools and self-correction.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language IV
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL321Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

2 hrs in-class lecture + 1 hr online asynchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed for students who wish to consolidate and perfect their writing abilities. Skills developped include the mastery of register-based differences; use of rhetorical and stylistic techniques; systematic self-correction; and the advanced use of reference tools including on-line dictionaries.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language V: Written French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL421Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

Information regarding the classroom associated with this course will be provided to students through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed for students who wish to consolidate and perfect their speaking abilities. This is accomplished through the preparation of longer oral productions involving a rich vocabulary and contextually-appropriate speech registers. Focus on overall pronunciation including fine phonetic detail and fluency.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language V: Oral French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL421Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Not open to fluent or native speakers of French.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Fiction and Non-Fiction in French

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 12, 2021: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: An online course designed for students who wish to further develop their reading and writing skills in French. Students will acquire analytic tools to comprehend, analyze and write fiction and non-fiction texts. Multimedia approach to understanding the cultural experiences of francophone world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Reading and Writing Fiction and Non-Fiction in French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL375Y1/(FSL375H1 and 0.5 credit in FRE at the 200-level)

cmCourseInfo.description: Putting students in diverse speaking and listening situations and contexts, this course is designed for those who wish to consolidate and perfect their speaking and listening abilities and take them to the next level. Focusing on a contextual approach of both oral and aural French and various francophone cultures, this course will focus on various aspects and difficulties that come with speaking and understanding French in real-life situations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Oral French in Context
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL375Y1/(FSL375H1 and 0.5 credit in FRE at the 200-level)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Not open to fluent or native speakers of French.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.
